source.raw_text:
The Suitcase Carry is a unilateral loaded carry that trains anti-lateral flexion, strengthening your core (obliques, transverse abdominis, QL), grip, shoulders (deltoids, traps, rotator cuff), upper back (lats, rhomboids), and lower body stabilizers (glutes, quads, hips) to resist side-bending while walking. The core movement pattern involves maintaining a tall, upright posture and preventing the weight on one side from pulling you down, mimicking everyday tasks like carrying groceries or luggage, promoting balance, stability, and functional strength. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Core: Obliques, Transverse Abdominis, Quadratus Lumborum (QL) (primary stabilizers against side bending). 
• Upper Body: Forearms & Grip, Deltoids, Traps, Lats, Rhomboids (shoulder stability, arm strength). 
• Lower Body: Glutes, Hip Stabilizers, Quads, Hamstrings, Calves (balance and hip alignment). [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Setup: Stand tall, shoulders back and down, chest out, holding a heavy dumbbell or kettlebell in one hand at your side, away from your body. 
2. Action: Walk slowly and deliberately, focusing on staying upright. 
3. Core Engagement (Anti-Lateral Flexion): Your core muscles (especially the obliques on the opposite side) contract isometrically to prevent your torso from tilting or bending towards the weight. 
4. Maintain Posture: Keep your hips level and avoid leaning away from the weight. 
5. Repetition: Walk a set distance or time, then switch hands. [1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10, 11]  

Why It's Effective 

• Functional Strength: Trains your body to handle uneven loads, like real-life tasks. 
• Core Stability: Excellent for developing strong, stable, and resilient core muscles. 
• Improves Posture: Strengthens back and core muscles to maintain an upright stance. 
• Unilateral Training: Addresses strength imbalances between sides, which often develop from daily activities. [1, 2, 3, 4, 10]
